name: customer
troubleshooting: Sometimes, other customers will take offence to seeing a mother breastfeeding or expressing in one of our stores. If you receive a complaint from a customer you may advise them that this is a women's right under Australian Federal Law.
If you are uncomfortable, unsure, or if the complaint escalates seek help from your Store Manager.
constraints: In Australian Federal Law, breastfeeding is a right, not a privilege.
Under the federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984 it is illegal in Australia to discriminate against a person either directly or indirectly on the grounds of breastfeeding.
This means, a woman has the right to breastfeed, or express milk, anywhere she chooses. This includes our stores.
No one should ever be asked by a team member to cover themselves or stop breastfeeding or expressing anywhere in our stores. This includes in fitting rooms or on the shop floor.
Service standards must be adhered to at all times.
caveats: If any of the above Customer Service Standards creates a threatening situation or aggressive behaviour from the customer, always adhere to the 5Ds and threatening situations. Report the incident to a manager discreetly.
bestPractice: Seek help from your Store Manager if you are unsure.
Welcome each customer as they enter the store with a greeting and a smile.
Assist customers with enquiries such as product locations and direct customers for refunds or exchanges to the Service Desk, and alert the team via P2T.
Report suspicious behaviour discreetly using P2T whilst adhering to the Managing Threatening Situations - 4Ds Poster.
Monitor trolley and basket availability and use P2T to notify a manager if replenishment is required.
Farewell each customer and ask if they found everything they were looking for.
Request the receipt to scan as per the receipt scan process and conduct bag checks to ensure the total items on the receipt match what is in their bag, trolley, pram, or box.
Ask for assistance to queue bust while checking receipts with the receipt scanner.
